columns.name: Description
columns.description: Longer explanation of project

cachedContents.largest: You say the flushers and faucets don't work? Ick! Please vote to upgrade these facilities that are used by ~1,000 students each day. If you do, we'll have safer, cleaner, more sustainable bathrooms!

top.item: New Laptops and Technology for 8 schools.
Installation of tamper-proof security cameras with high picture quality in public housing complexes.
Installation of 4-6 SMART Boards or Tables at 7 schools

An installment towards the total cost of providing security cameras in the following developments: East River Houses ($200,000), Douglass I, II, and Addition ($100,000), Johnson Houses ($100,000), and Millbrook Houses ($100,000). This funding allocation would only cover a portion of the overall cost for these cameras, with a significant cost remaining for each development.
Project will be designed to budget in collaboration with the Resident Association leadership. Priorities to be considered will include lighting, trees, bushes, irrigation system and metal benches
Replacing asphalt, fencing and greening to beautify areas within the development. (designed to budget).
Install countdown clocks to keep pedestrians safe at 10 dangerous intersections.
This proposal is for 1/3 of the cost of new stalls, updated plumbing, improved signage for comfort station/restroom.
4 security cameras boxes, with 2 cameras per box, will help deter crime and enhance public safety at this location.
Countdown clocks at select bus stations will inform riders how far away the next bus is. There will be 15 clocks in total.
Repair and resurface roadways that have been identified as dangerous due to potholes, ridges and other damage.

The streets are starting to wear out after years of improper care, resulting in dangerous cracks and potholes that cause accidents. White lanes have not been repainted, thus heightening the potential for accidents (for motorists and pedestrians) and irresponsible driving.
Upgrade the fitness equipment, which will enhance the public health benefits of the neighborhood.
Much-needed updates to a number of restrooms as student performance directly relates to well maintained facilities.
Installation of new benches and fountains
Install eight police-monitored Argus cameras to deter crimes in vulnerable public areas.
The school will receive two mobile laptop carts.
Install Argus security cameras at intersections where NYPD precincts have identified a need. Each Argus unit is a set of 2 cameras. Three units will be allocated to each of the 2 precincts.
Add new security cameras for increased safety for residents of Holmes Towers.

cachedContents.smallest: 10 trees with enhanced pits will improve storm drainage, and add shade and beauty in Gowanus from Bond St. to 3rd Ave

columns.name: BP Funding
columns.description: Some projects reiceve additional funding from a Borough President. "1" means the project will receive funding from a Borough President and "0" means the project did not receive funding from a Borough President

Public Design Commission (formerly Art Commission (ARTCOM) and Design Commission)
fields.name: Agency

view.description:
Participatory Budgeting is a democratic process in which community members directly decide how to spend part of a public budget. Council Members choose to join Participatory Budgeting New York City (PBNYC), giving at least $1 million from their budget for the whole community to participate in decision-making. It’s a yearlong process of public meetings, to ensure that people have the time and resources to make informed decisions. Community members discuss local needs and develop proposals to meet these needs. Through a public vote, residents then decide which proposals to fund.

More info can be found at http://council.nyc.gov/pb/
view.emailShareUrl: mailto:?subject=Participatory Budgeting Projects&body=Here is a dataset from NYC Open Data that I would like to share with you: https%3A%2F%2Fdata.cityofnewyork.us%2FCity-Government%2FParticipatory-Budgeting-Projects%2Fwwhr-5ven

coreView.description:
Participatory Budgeting is a democratic process in which community members directly decide how to spend part of a public budget. Council Members choose to join Participatory Budgeting New York City (PBNYC), giving at least $1 million from their budget for the whole community to participate in decision-making. It’s a yearlong process of public meetings, to ensure that people have the time and resources to make informed decisions. Community members discuss local needs and develop proposals to meet these needs. Through a public vote, residents then decide which proposals to fund.
 
More info can be found at http://council.nyc.gov/pb/
